title: James with Acute Calf Muscle Tear
clinical_history: James is a 42-year-old recreational football player who was participating in a local weekend soccer tournament. While sprinting towards the goal, he suddenly experienced a sharp, stabbing pain in the back of his right lower leg, causing him to stop abruptly and subsequently fall to the ground. He had immediate difficulty bearing weight on his right leg and described the sensation as feeling like he was 'shot' in the calf.

nprs.affected_area: right calf, primarily the medial gastrocnemius muscle
occasional radiating pain to the ankle

aggrevating_factors: weight-bearing activities, especially walking and going up on toes, rapid movements
picture: [insert image of a person highlighting the medial part of the right calf]
easing_factors: rest, elevation of the limb, application of ice packs
past_history: No significant previous lower limb injuries. Patient has a history of mild sprains in the ankle region during past sports activities but recovered without complications.
medical_history: Generally healthy; no chronic medical conditions. Quit smoking 5 years ago and maintains a balanced diet.
medications: Occasional use of over-the-counter ibuprofen for pain relief, currently taking as needed for current pain.
personal_history: Works as a software engineer, married with two teenage children. Exercises regularly, mostly through sports like soccer and running. Reports stress at work over tight project deadlines.
imaging: An ultrasound scan confirmed a partial tear in the medial head of the gastrocnemius muscle with surrounding edema and hematoma formation.
